title: State v. Marcus Thompson - Juvenile Transfer Evaluation
court: Juvenile Court, King County Superior Court, Washington
question: Whether defendant should be transferred from juvenile to adult court for prosecution of aggravated assault charges; amenability to rehabilitation within juvenile justice system
summary: 17-year-old male with conduct disorder and substance use history evaluated for transfer to adult court following aggravated assault. Evaluation examines developmental factors, mental health diagnoses, treatment history, and rehabilitation potential within juvenile versus adult systems.

documents.description: Comprehensive forensic psychiatric evaluation addressing transfer criteria, including clinical interviews, collateral information review, and amenability assessment
Detailed developmental and psychosocial history compiled from interviews with defendant, family members, and review of educational and treatment records
Structured risk assessment using SAVRY (Structured Assessment of Violence Risk in Youth) and analysis of recidivism factors
Direct and cross-examination testimony regarding clinical findings, amenability to treatment, and recommendations on transfer decision

key_findings: Diagnosis of Conduct Disorder, Childhood-Onset Type, Severe with limited prosocial emotions
History of Cannabis Use Disorder, Moderate, currently in controlled environment
Significant adverse childhood experiences including exposure to domestic violence and parental substance abuse
SAVRY risk assessment indicates moderate-high risk with presence of protective factors including intellectual functioning in average range and family support
Prior juvenile interventions were insufficient intensity; defendant showed partial response to structured residential treatment
Neuropsychological testing revealed executive functioning deficits consistent with adolescent brain development
Assessment indicates moderate amenability to rehabilitation with intensive, evidence-based interventions available in juvenile system
Transfer to adult system would likely eliminate access to developmentally appropriate treatment and education services
